Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spikelets in groups of 5–7, one bisexual, the rest male or sterile (sometimes very reduced and/or deformed), falling as a group at maturity
Spikelets all bisexual (except sometimes near the base of the inflorescence), persistent
Perennial; pedicels glabrous; stem bases tuberous; lower spikelets of each group mostly male only; wing of glumes with several small teeth near apex; panicle purplish

Annual; pedicels hairy; lower spikelets of each group sterile (lacking lemmas); stem bases not tuberous; wing of glumes of fertile spikelets with 1 prominent tooth near apex; panicle usually light green
Glumes lacking broad wings along keel; panicle often lobed
Glumes conspicuously winged along keel; panicle cylindric to ovoid, not or very rarely lobed
Perennial with long rhizomes; fertile lemma flattened
Sterile lemmas unequal or only one developed; annual or perennial
Perennial; glumes entire; panicle to 15 cm long
Annual; glumes with a toothed or notched wing; panicle rarely exceeding 5 cm
Spikelets 6–9 mm long; fertile lemmas more than 4 mm long, 1.5–2 times the length of sterile lemmas
Spikelets less than 5 mm long; fertile lemmas less than 4 mm long, c. 3 times the length of sterile lemmas
